instruction: Categorize the comment on the basis of obscenity. If the comment is obscene output Yes, otherwise output No.
input: I have a lot of experience with GOP family and co-workers. I can even bring up an idea or a proposal, and they may be for or against it on the basis of the information involved. instruction: Categorize the comment on the basis of obscenity. If the comment is obscene output Yes, otherwise output No.
input: Larry, your historical research is lacking on this. Study the Republican administrations of the 1920s, for example -- as well as earlier -- and you'll find no (or very little) support for your assertions that Republicans believed that government needs to be large enough to ensure every citizen has a decent standard of living. They had other reasons for favoring a strong central government, but they had very little (if any) concern for the livelihoods of ordinary citizens. William Leuchtenberg's new (huge!) volume titled The American Presidency: From Teddy Roosevelt to Bill Clinton will give you a good overview, if you're interested. You're right that the Democrats changed in the 1930s, but they weren't switching places with Republicans (not at that point, that happened much later).

instruction: Categorize the comment on the basis of obscenity. If the comment is obscene output Yes, otherwise output No.
input:
The Western Kenai Peninsula underwent major logging prescriptions for "salvage logging"  using fire as the excuse and basis of fear to move this forward with few safeguards for the rest of the ecosystem.  Water sampling parameters were taken for many years showing water temperature increases.  The areas opened up became hot spots.  They also became deserts in the winter for moose with no cover.  The Forest Practices Act had a 66 foot buffer which of course does nothing to cool water temperatures and most of this blows down.  The Forest Health Initiative in 1993 alluded to the fact that during the Pot Hole lake fire the spruce Bark Beetle trees actually slowed the path of fire.  It declared the cure is worse than the disease.
The Timber Task Force and the State foresters on the other hand pushed hard using scare tactics to open logging as fast as possible.  Circle D E came in along with other small operators, bringing their own workers...they went bankrupt.  Alaska once again lost.
